reviews.review: Gun

CS:GO came out over 3,500 days ago, almost 10 years. Since 2014, CS:GO has never had less than 250,000 concurrent players. Many games in the last decade which are considered cornerstones of PC gaming, possibly even cornerstones of FPS games in general, never even achieved that many concurrent players at their absolute peak. In 2020, CS:GO hit its all time peak of over a million concurrent players playing all at the same time, an achievement that is likely only shared with truly Earth-shatteringly popular games like LoL and WoW. This is all to say that somehow, despite being almost a decade old, CS:GO remains one of the most popular titles on PC as a whole, beating out such rivals as Apex Legends, Valorant, Warzone, PUBG, Rainbow Six Siege, and pretty much every other FPS game you can let roll off the tongue, and likely any non-shooter title you can think of as well. I would venture to say that no game aside from Minecraft and PONG has had even remotely close to the staying power of CS:GO. 

All that said, the game blows. Modern CS:GO looks dated, sounds dated, and plays like Valve's 1998 Half-Life. Source has completely knee-capped any opportunity for growth and innovation, and with a few minor meta changes and the introduction of new gamemodes and weapons, CS:GO is the same game now that it was 3,500 days ago. Some would argue that this is a sign of perfection, of effortless staying power, but I would argue that it is a sign of a lazy cash grab. Let's be honest, in comparison to modern competitors, CS:GO's movement is incredibly clunky. You can draw a direct lineage between crouch-jumping mid-doors on Dust II to completing puzzles in Black Mesa in Half Life. CS:GO is likely the only game about using firearms that does not allow you to ADS and more or less guarantees the user that the bullets coming from their firearm will not hit what they are looking at unless they have perfect movement, aim, and spray-pattern knowledge. Rất few weapons have been added in the last decade, and those that have been added are generally worse in every measurable way to those that they replace. Dust II remains the most popular map and has itself only seen a light graphical upgrade with only a small handful of map design changes. New maps are introduced, regularly complained about, and removed from the current map pool. If you are reading this in 2032, Dust II is likely still the most popular map and likely remains un-upgraded. 

Socially, the game is terrible. The vast majority of the user base is either incredibly toxic, racist, cheating, or a combination of all three. The way that matchmaking works, it is easy to come across smurf after smurf after smurf, losing game after game after game to players who's real skill is likely 10x higher than CS:GO placed them. I cannot begin to count the number of games in which I was subjected to player's profile pictures that were outright pornographic or I was called racial or homophobic slurs. "Toxic" does not even begin to describe how inhumane the CS:GO community can be at times. 

So thus far, I have established that CS:GO is one of the most popular games on PC that has time and time again outlasted better competitors, I have dogpiled the game for looking, sounding, and playing like a game from 1998, and I have called all of the userbase toxic cheaters. If I believe all of these things, how can I possibly recommend the game? Easy - I only play CS:GO with friends. I play for fun and to collect skins. Many an hour has been spent, three or four beers deep, just chatting and joking with friends with CS:GO on in the background. Three, four, or even five-stacking pub matches is incredible fun. Playing the game in a public lobby where you and your friends work through elaborate, practiced routines of memes and jokes with poor, unsuspecting randoms is easily one of the funniest things you can do with a microphone and PC. Stupendous fun can be had when you find a player who has a sense of humor who will joke around with you as much as you with them. Every game is a win when you play with friends - you either lose the game so that your skill rating drops and you get to pub stomp the next lobby, or you win the game and your skill rating increases so that you can get pub stomped next game, thus setting you up for your own pub stomp. This circuitous motion is what keeps the game fun and fresh, you either get dumpstered on, dumpster a team, or the CS:GO matchmaking works for once and you have to fight for your life to get that 15:15. CS:GO sucks as a game, and you will never, ever see me playing it alone. But as a medium by which you can interact with your friends, CS:GO is unbeatable. Put a 30-rack in the fridge, get some T-Bell delivered, and get four friends who cannot hit the accept button with their aim and I guarantee you will make a life-long meme between the five of you.

i've beat this game far too many times, made so many friends while playing and i must say this has to got to be one of the best and scariest gaming experiences i ever had. the randomization of the game is great, as you either spawn in and see literally 0 cannibals or the whole village rolls up on you. it may also make your life of finding food and water easy or extremely difficult because the damn deer have weird hitboxes and run annoyingly fast. the darkness in this game is incredible, as it is genuinely impossible to see if you don't have any light sources. the caves are genuinely horrifying, as they are extremely dark and the cannibals scream at you from the darkness. the way you and your friends begin screaming when an armsy charges you in a cave or a group of cannibals rushes at you is something you never experience in other games. while the game can be non-serious at times, i believe it is a great horror experience and everyone should give it a shot.

Really good survival game spilled with a huge map, crafting, horror and an okay story. I played with the Early Access version back when it first launched and I already liked it. The game is now finished, has a proper story and you can play trough it without any issues. Not gonna lie, when I started playing the game I got addicted to it so much, that I only put it down when I got all the Achievements, and finished the story itself. Since then, I never really touched it. So I completed it on normal and decided to give it another try on Hard difficulty with my dudes. It's a little bit hard for them, because they just started playing it and never knew anything about the game, but they're at least enjoying it. I don't exactly know if I would complete this game alone once again, it's more fun and faster with other players.

I'm 63 and have been playing video games since the Odyssey system. That being said, Subnautica has been my favorite gaming experience in all that time; the best game ever.
I don't review games in general, but this game deserves an exception. It is an amazing experience.
its a horror game

[b]Positives[/b]

+ Gorgeous, varied alien sea planet that is teeming with life and great to explore.
+ Tons of alien creatures and fauna with data entries explaining life on the planet.
+ Large map with lots of different biomes to explore and places to find.
+ All of the vehicles work really well and have their own distinct purpose. They’re all great, but the Prawn Suit in particular is absolutely badass and a mech done great.
+ A lot of puzzle solving. Feels like a great achievement to beat the game.
+ Ranges from fun tropical paradise, to mysterious and alien, to murky horror.
+ The music can really amplify the mood of each area.
+ Resource-gathering gameplay works well and never feels too grindy.
+ Lots of tools at your disposal with different purposes.
+ Lots you can build and do with your habitat home. If you like base-building, there's a lot for you to play around with here.
+ Really good story despite a silent protagonist and lack of characters and dialogue.
+ Rất immersive and gripping in general.

[b]Negatives[/b]

- In some parts my vehicle, in particular the Prawn Suit, could get stuck on parts of the terrain. Worth noting I only had to reload once from this (Sea Moth got stuck on part of the Aurora and couldn't be moved) and it was primarily with the Prawn Suit on land sections which are rare anyway.
- I think a craftable tool to allow for mapping out your surroundings for reference would have helped greatly rather than relying on memory and beacons constantly for waypoints. This is very subjective however, I'm sure some others would say adding that in would have taken away from the exploration and experience of getting familiar with your environment. For me, I would have felt less of a draw to look up guides if I could see where I had been plotted out and start marking off where I had been and where I wanted to go next.

[b]Conclusion[/b]

Subnautica is a very unique experience and one I would highly recommend. I think the part that hit me most is when I realised I was actually nearing being able to escape the planet, and I realised how immersed I was in the world, having been stuck in the seas and gradually built up a base that had actually become somewhat homely and familiar and realising it was all going to be left behind. The fact the game made me feel that way shows how immersive it had all been. There’s nothing quite like Subnautica, it’s a fantastic deep sea exploration game. I will admit I used a guide to direct me around in parts which I would advise against for others, I just personally find the deep sea pretty spooky e.g. coming out over the edge of a cliff and there’s just murky nothingness stretching out around you in all directions and the potential for a looming shape off in the depths that you are powerless against. On the flip side, that should speak volumes for how immersive the game is and how it can be pretty scary in parts depending on how much the deep sea spooks you out.

One of my favorites.   Once I learned where things were for replay, I could avoid most dangerous encounters by simply not going there or swimming or driving away from it.   So much can be done, built and created, but its very unnecessary to "win" the game.   I would love to see more of this exact building scenario with a deeper story requiring other buildings (scanner building hardly if ever needed - helped with finding stalker teeth but not necessary), more open environment perhaps, and maybe a reason to build some of it.  Maybe a reason to get the upper tier power plants would be "necessary" for creating the ion powered battery or for operating a certain size structure.   Or maybe a stronger energy to supply the vehicle factory to build a sub vs just the regular energy for a Seamoth construction.   On a difficulty level of 0-10, this is a 4, imo.   I like the ease of some of the game, but it never really gets difficult.  

To developers:

Maybe these things could happen with a 3rd release with a new scenario, obviously stranded, and having a puzzle or situation to solve is always the goal.    I did not need most of the buildings, or the prawn suit, and even swam through the game, even in lava zones,  without the extra strength suit (granted with health packs) and was able to solve or win the game.   I only built the sub to get the shield add-on needed for the escape spaceship.   The first time playing, I built everything and experienced most of the intended horrors, which was great!   I have hundreds of hours on this game and still love it in general.    It would be neat to have a surprise creature now and then, (not too often), but to throw a random in it somewhere not expected.   Perhaps it can be a different creature not usually seen or a random Leviathan that swims through an area (but not like clockwork) or attracted to power sources and a device is needed to short term (battery) mask the power-source or repel the creature.. Maybe like a slow moving Leviathan Shark that IF not not seen approaching and avoided, it just swallows you.  (dead - keeping the unknown fear up)..   Maybe a little damage done to a building that would need repairs, as it is there is little repair needed if you keep your level above zero.   I only had damage when a Reaper got stuck in the shallows and his thrashing damaged some of my base.   He had followed my sea-moth one time back to the shallows and another I believe I had brought an egg and dropped it below my base for lack of storage near the beginning.   I did not see a hatching but it was there when I got back one time and I could not get rid of it and was not sure how or why it was there (unless it was a glitch).

At times, the food and water are excessive.   I would like to see a daily need for food and water, rather than by the minute, for more realism.   I DO understand the need after a long swim needing replenishing but while driving around a Seamoth, I shouldn't be so thirsty and hungry, because the timer is running.   In RL, we can go 3 days without water without dying and 3 weeks without food in real life, so...  The necessity for a sleep cycle would be great too.   Even if its just sitting without a bed to rest with a bed sleep mode energizing more.   ( so a third meter on need for sleep or rest maybe?  just not excessive again, but more realistic timeline needed.)

I still give the game a thumbs up and suggest everyone play it!    For a bigger challenge, do the hard mode where you have no warnings of loss of air and suddenly you are not close enough to get to the surface or back to a Seamoth, base, etc.  Game over, start all over, from the beginning.

This is a game that will go down in history as another game that both defies classification and makes its own. This is truly a work of art and I am EXTREMELY glad to say I've finally, after nearly seven years, finished it.

Why did it take seven years? Simply put, you are not the biggest fish in the sea. There are things that will EAT you for a snack. And that is terrifying. That, and I'd get distracted by other things and loose interest, only to come back time after time. The story starts out simple, then gets complicated and very intriguing and just gets better from there.

From resource gathering in the safe shallows, to much more dangerous areas, this *custom made map* (maybe random tech parts, but the map is static) is designed to be a challenge, but also give the player the utmost in freedom to explore, build and work the story their own way. Or, you can just ignore the story, build a base, and stay on 4546B for as long as you like.

Folks, as I said, this game has taken me almost seven years to complete one playthrough from start to finish. It took over two hundred and sixty game-days to finally complete. Sure, there were some terrifying parts in there (Leviathans anyone?) but every minute of each of those days I enjoyed, one way or the other.

Folks, I don't often give a thumbs UP for a game. Most of my reviews are meh or downright bad. This one, this one is a diamond in the rough. Get it. Enjoy it. Just remember. There are bigger things out there then you. And they're hungry.

Love it in VR playing, but really missing more mech customization, part changing, different characteristics e.t.c If developers add more of that things game will be better than Mech Warrior. Developers hope you will not abandon this project.

Fantatsic support for HOTAS setup, using an X52 is seamless so you have the option to use the virtual controls or physical controls depending on your preference. 

On top of that really satisfying mech combat.

This is a great mech game, similar to Mechwarrior. It's even more immersive due to the VR integration!
The online matches are fun and fast-paced! Had to change my man-diaper a couple of times after getting rammed head-on by many mechs, while getting my arms blown off by laser sniper mechs. Fun times. The single player campaign has some really funny dialogue and pretty cool ship you can explore between missions. The mech A.I. companion and your robot mechanic buddy are the highlights of the campaign.

The mechs control more like walking tanks (Mechwarrior series, Steel Battalion, Shattered Steel) while you sit in the cockpit, as opposed to your average third-person super robot fantasy b.s. that you would find in Gundam and Armored core 
/start rant.exe (the creators of *those* series choose to let their mecha have feet, yet the mecha always seem to fly or hover everywhere... why? You have access to energy weapons and ballistics, but you end up choosing a lazer sword in a long range combat scenario?? again I must ask, WHY?!? Stupid gundam fantasy b.s. )/ end rant.

TL; DR
Big beefy stompy boi mechs that pew pew everything, and *you* are in drivers seat. Rất fun. Rất good. Much praise!

When I first saw this game I thought it might be kind of similar to the game 'Rune Factory: Frontier' which I had played on the Wii.  I've eagerly awaited a port for PC but as of yet it currently can only be played on PC using an emulator.  Stardew Valley gave off some very similar vibes though so I thought maybe it might be close enough to sort of fill that same gap.

The game starts out simple enough, your grandfather left you a farm and you need to work to repair it and get it up and running again.  You chop logs, break rocks, till soil, plant seeds and harvest your crops.  There's a  lot of room to play around with your farm and where you want to place things.  There's also a foraging aspect which helps encourage exploration of your surroundings too.  The game is more than just a farming sim though, it also has RPG elements and you can battle monsters in the mines that in turn drop loot you can use or sell.  In addition to that it has some adventure game aspects such quests and some fairly light puzzles.  You can date and marry certain people in the town and even have two kids.  Later in the game you can even forge your own weapons and equipment and add specific power-ups to them.

I grew up on pixel graphics so I found the graphics to be somewhat nostalgic feeling.  The animations are fairly simple and the character sprites very 2D but the characters themselves, not so much.  Each character has a bit of a backstory and unique character traits you get to know as you build friendship points.  At certain levels of friendship you're given the treat of special little cut scenes.  You get to make choices on how you respond to the cut-scenes too.  Sometimes it can help your relationship or hurt it.  This adds quite a bit of story elements to the game.

Part of the beauty of this game is that you can play it in so many ways.  If you just want to have a calm farming experience, growing crops, playing around with aesthetics or optimal functionality in your builds, then you can play it that way.  The music in the game somehow manages a great balance of calming and upbeat.  If you want a little more excitement you can delve deep in the different mines and battle a variety of monsters and collecting and crafting better gear.  If you like adventure then you'll probably want to work on completing quests and solving the puzzles.  If you're more into stories you'll probably enjoy making friends with everyone and exploring their personalities.  Really, there's a little something for everyone and enough content that if you get bored there's something else to try.

In the early game it really feels like completing the community tasks mounts to a climax.  It's easy little goals to attain and strive for but once you finish the community center that's really just the beginning of the game.  You can unlock other mines, a desert, and an Island.  The game is much more expansive than you will first anticipate and it's possible that the developer may release future expansions to bring even more content and explorable areas.  The game does have a sort of "ending" in which you'll see a special cut scene but you can keep playing on so the game doesn't ever truly end.  You can also create a new character to play again from the beginning.  There are different farm types that present different challenges and benefits which make for a little replay-ability.

In addition to different maps you can also play this game in co-op mode with friends.  I don't personally like multi-player experiences, I prefer solo adventures, but I do like that if you chose to play this way each character can have their own house and while you can work together, you can also go off and do your own thing.  You aren't limited to the host's farm or experiences and guests can upgrade their cabin, get married, and essentially experience everything the games has to offer.

There are really only two things I disliked about this game.  First, there's the save function, you can only save by going to sleep (or ending the day by falling asleep outside your home/bed or "dying" in the mines {you can't actually die you just get beat to within inches of your life apparently}).  Sleeping ends the day and your game progress is saved.  However, I often find that I have to leave my game in the middle of a day when I don't have time or the ability to finish my day or even run to my bed so I can save.  Instead, I had to open the menu, which pauses the game, and then either just leave it running in the foreground or if I had to do something on my computer, let it run in the background till I could get back to the game.  So, for example, at the time of writing this review, Steam has 1,062.9 hours logged playing this game.  However, between my two save files I only have about 509 hours logged in-game.  So, it spent about half the time sitting open in the background on my computer simply because I could hit a save button and continue later.

The second thing I didn't like was the fishing mini-game.  I've played plenty of games that have fishing mini-games in them and they are all similar but all have their own unique flair... this one is the worst fishing mini-game I've ever played.  Maybe other people found it easy but I couldn't get how to catch fish.  There's something to do with patterns and clicking at the right times but I completely failed at it every time.  The only thing that made fishing redeemable was actually a mod that let me skip the mini-game portion.  While I don't necessarily advocate mods, I found the game partially unplayable because of this mini-game and it was really ruining my personal experience with playing the game.  The mod made the game playable and fun again.

Mods are actually one of the things that for some players could be a real plus side to the game.  Stardew Valley has a fairly large modding community with mods for everything from changing the NPC's dialogue avatar to skipping fishing mini-games to adding elevators to creating new expanded areas to explore.  If you find yourself too frustrated with an aspect of the game, there's probably a mod for it.  If you love mods for games you'll love this game.

The last thing I'd like to touch on is the game's achievements.  There's 40 of them which is a fair amount and most will unlock naturally over time with normal gameplay, but there are several collection based achievements that you have to work for.  Many of those require a lot of hours of game play.  For example, if you want to catch all the fish you won't be able to do it unless you fish in every season, some require reaching maximum friendships which can take a lot of time to build, and of course others require you to get a huge sum of money.  Collectible items are gained through RNG drops so even if you do everything right you could be doing it a long time to get those drops you need.  For completionists, like me, that can be very frustrating and it's a big part of why I had to put in about 500 hours to get all the achievements.  It could be a lot less or even more depending on your luck with the RNG.

Overall, this game is a gem, I don't usually recommend games at full retail price, but I'd say this one is actually worth it.

Let me start by saying I absolutely LOVE this game. Iv'e currently got just over 410 hours played. That's just over 17 days back to back nonstop. It's like battlefield but slightly more intense. One bullet to kill for most rifles under 200 meters. But I cannot justify at this moment, suggesting someone to buy it. This is a community based game, there is no story, no real progression other than getting a few different load outs with certain roles. As a min/maxer, progression is usually needed but not here. The games are interactive, heart pounding, and absolutely terrifying in some cases. If you are sitting there thinking this sounds fun so far, it is, INCREDIBLY so. But as a new player, you have a very difficult challenge ahead of you. There is no tutorial as of April 16th, 2022, so anything you want to learn about the game or how to play, you need to study. That means talk to other players, only during an active match tho, or watch videos and guides on youtube. This leads to long time players resenting newer players. As a new player, you will only bring your teams effectiveness down (solely because you have not been taught the game). I don't blame the players or the community, I solely blame the devs for this. Hell Let Loose matches DEPEND on ALL players of a team, and I love this about this game. It's not just about killing, but squads working together to form a whole unit/team. But the game ITSELF does not tell you this, or at least in an effective way. And that is why I blame the developers and cannot recommend, at this time, that you purchase this game. I want this game to become more popular and to become a model for future war/military games. And I want more players and more servers, but until the issue of teaching new players how to play this game is addressed, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. You will get yelled at, kicked out of games, and this can lead to a resentment for this game and the players. Just keep this game on your wishlist until you see the issues here being addressed.

Edit: Some things are being taken out of context, My main issue with this game is the lack of in-game information about the game and the importance of certain things. Examples being garrisons, squad roles and their uses, positioning, how redzones work, things of the sort. There is very basic information explaining what they are BUT NOT WHY they are useful. As a player, and not a developer, I have no control over installing an in depth tutorial. I cannot change anything about the workings of the game and neither can you. Only a developer can add/remove things from the game itself. A tutorial would fall under this category. That is why I have a problem with the developers. As far as community goes, I could lie to people and say every person in the community is a great person and only wants to help, while that rings true for MOST, it does not take away from the fact that you WILL experience negative people or "rude" people. IF that is someones FIRST impression, it's not a good one and can have a negative effect on the new player, tainting their first experience WHILE not understanding the game either. This is my point towards the "community" aspect in regards to a new players perspective of the game. A good first impression is a good one, a bad one is bad. Not understanding the game AND having a bad first impression can push people away from the game.


TL;DR: Game needs a tutorial for new players. Too steep a learning curve that can ruin matches for long term and new players when an influx of first time players (specifically lacking the knowledge of how the game works)  joins the game. This isn't call of duty and the game does not specify why it is not.

Thank you to everyone interacting and commenting on this, I understand I may not be perfectly clear on my points so I appreciate you keeping me in check and calling me out. Just don't forget, the only reason I don't recommend this game is lack of tutorial. This is by far my favorite and most played game, I'm just trying to make it easier for when brand new, first time players join the game. A tutorial can provide the necessary information to help ease new players in.

I don't normally like PvP games and I am total rubbish at them.

Typically I wouldn't recommend this sort of game, however this game drips atmosphere.  The Saving Private Ryan comparisons are obvious because it feels like you are experiencing a movie when you play.   Just watch a few videos on Youtube of the gameplay and you will see what I mean.

Expect to die a lot in this game.    Most times I die without ever seeing the enemy and I assume they are prone in the grass/bushes.   It can get frustrating when you are prone in a trench with sandbags on either side of you and the enemy still gets a headshot on you.   As long as you go into this game with a healthy attitude about possibly being the worst player on your team you will do fine.

I am specially bad at single fire weapons because if you miss that first shot on the enemy you will be the one dying.   I tend to stick to classes that allow me the ability to spray bullets since my accuracy is horrible.

Cheaters are thing with this game of course.   Last night I witnessed an enemy we couldn't kill even with automatic, single fire, bazookas, and MG all firing on him from about 100m away.  He was the first person I could confirm was cheating.     The worst part of PvP games like this is the paranoia that sets in when you are killed from unseen enemies.  This happens a lot with this game.   It will drive you nuts if you think everyone is cheating.

Some classes unlock automatic weapons once you reach the 3rd level ranking (for instance Support).    I recommend you look through the classes and decide upon a class you want to level up.

The medic class doesn't have much ammo and is completely useless for offensive.   Reviving your downed team mates is a good way to not feel completely useless though.   Everyone loves a medic that goes prone and crawls through gunfire to revive a downed player.    Many people do not recommend to bother with the 3rd level unlocks for a medic (the ability to spawn medic supplies is really not needed and not worth losing a primary weapon for).
It just feels like how you imagine the Second World War. It just feels right.

If you loved the original Subnautica, you'll at least like this game. I found that, throughout my entire play through, the whole experience didn't feel nearly as mysterious and terrifying as the first game. In BZ, they replaced the huge, open map with a small, almost linear one. While some may like that, I didn't personally; I loved the huge areas of purely dark water with no visible bottom (obviously excluding the void) and the excitement of exploring these uncharted waters. In BZ, however, since there was an entire team of scientists, engineers, etc. in the area to begin with, it feels like the entire map's already been explored, which discouraged me from exploring it. The biomes don't feel nearly as unique as they did in Subnautica; they almost blend together. 

The story is okay. It's nothing life changing. Now, the original's wasn't either, but it was at least different. There are two main story lines in BZ: the one regarding the death of Robin's sister and the one about helping AL-AN. The latter has an interesting ending, and goes into the Architects in greater detail, but the one with Sam is just boring. I didn't care at all about the Sam story line; I had no incentive to find out what happened to her. It was, frankly, boring.

Overall, if you loved the original  you should definitely try BZ; while it's not as good, it gives you more of the Subnautica experience, but in a different fashion. While the original is a 10/10, BZ is probably a 7/10 for me.

[h1]🤢😞🙁😐🙂>😊<😍[/h1]
🐳 If there was only one thing I could tell you about Below Zero before you buy it, I would simply point at the Discussions in the Community Hub; the first thing you'll see there is an enormous thread called [i]'You ruined the game',[/i] which you shouldn't open due to the obvious spoilers galore that's inside. It's got way over a [b]thousand[/b] comments now, and people keep bickering there every single day:

[i]'Below Zero sucks! I hate it, it makes my blood boil!'[/i]
[i]'No, ya dimbo, it's great! I loved every second of it!'[/i]
...ad infinitum.

Despite the fact that a full year has elapsed since the game's release, neither the defence nor the prosecution have been able to make their closing arguments, 'rest their cases' and just go home. The smouldering embers of this dumpster fire just refuse to die, and I believe you can already draw some important conclusions based on that fact alone. People feel strongly about this game and the franchise in general.

I am one of those who loved Below Zero despite its shortcomings, but I will make an effort to remain impartial and unbiased in this review and explain both sides of the story. If you don't like going in blind with your entertainment purchases, stay awhile and I promise you'll come out the other side much better equipped to make a well-informed decision.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2796283190
🐋 The most resounding complaint, the overarching theme of all disparaging comments is the fact that the main heroine... [i]talks.[/i] The mute, expressionless dummy we controlled in the original installment is now replaced by Robin – a female researcher who is practically never at a loss for words. Some players attach significant importance to the atmosphere of utter loneliness and helplessness that was present in the previous game; for them, this atmosphere [i]is[/i] Subnautica. If you share this point of view, you're in for a nasty surprise – not only does Robin talk, but she's also not the only human being around. 

To be honest, I didn't mind the vocal protagonist and additional characters one bit – [i]on the contrary,[/i] I enjoyed the unusual flavour it gave to already familiar game mechanics. It felt fresh and I'm glad the devs decided against doing more of the same and in favour of being bold and creative. The lonely and helpless feel of the first game was born from the [b]absence[/b] of things – absence of ideas, absence of characters, absence of interactions; the product of natural limitations of a small studio, and barely the pinnacle of game design. 

🐡 The voiced heroine is not the only groundbreaking change, however. Anyone who's played the first part remembers that there were some land sections – a couple of small islands, if you don't count the Aurora. In Below Zero, land sections make a return, but now they're beefed up on steroids and occupy nearly 50% of the entire map – but we're still playing Sub[u]nautica,[/u] right?.. 

When on land, your body temperature drops at an alarming rate; thankfully, there is a variety of ways to keep it at optimal levels – the one you'll be using most often is jumping back into the freezing arctic water. 

Sure. Makes sense🤔

🐟 When not exploring snow-covered plains and mountain tops, you'll find that most ocean biomes are pretty crammed, with the majority of them being caves, ravines and twisting narrow passages of different kinds. I find that to be a pretty clever design choice; in the previous game, if you badly needed oxygen and safety, you could just... [i]go up.[/i] Here, directly up oftentimes leads nowhere, and the feeling of claustrophobia suddenly locks you in its wet, sickening embrace – especially if you have 10 seconds of oxygen left. To compensate for that, there are now oxygen plants sprinkled here and there throughout the dark depths, and you'll be frantically looking for them, praying to see that welcoming green glow around the next bend. This adds a whole other layer of emotional intensity that the original simply didn't have. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2800073898
🐠 Many players complain that this iteration of the series is guilty of 'handholding' you and does so in an annoying, obtrusive way; how I wish that was true! From the very beginning, you can go pretty much anywhere, but the story in Below Zero is presented in such a way that there is only one 'correct' path you may take that will allow all the little bits and pieces of the main plot you gather along the way to make sense. Unfortunately, I wasn't so lucky and didn't do things the 'intended' way; very often me and my partner were scratching our heads, completely stumped as to what the heck we were supposed to do next, and we had no such issues with the first game. The writing is sometimes sloppy and at odds with the story of the original. All that is one of the [b]two[/b] reasons I couldn't give Below Zero the 😍 rating.

🐬 The second one is the omnipresence of bugs and glitches, especially if you're brave (or stupid) enough to build your base on land. Things will constantly break for no reason at all; floating staircases, disappearing vehicles, the whole shebang. This is nothing new, as the first Subnautica also had similar problems, but this time the issues are pretty glaring and I have no idea how the devs missed them. 

🐚 On a more positive note, if there is truly something to pat Unknown Worlds Entertainment on the back about, that will be all the clever ideas they introduced in Below Zero; I couldn't help but say [i]'Oh, so now we have THIS!'[/i] nearly every time I sat down to play the game. One example of that would be the jukebox; you can now listen to music in your base and in your main vehicle as you explore the neverending cave systems, and every single song absolutely [i]slaps.[/i] They tried to include as many genres as possible; there are [b][url=https://youtu.be/E87WYWs4xZU?t=62]beautiful, unexpectedly emotional songs[/url][/b] that make exploration feel much more immersive than it was in the first game, and there is also... okay, sit down if you're standing – there is [i]Subnautica rap.[/i] This stuff starts at unbearable levels of cheese and comes full circle to being simply [b][url=https://youtu.be/RBdm83TdkeM?t=39]genius[/url][/b]. Never been a fan of rap music, but I appreciate the level of creativity that went into writing these lyrics. Overall, the presence of the jukebox spells death to the rather primitive (in my opinion) 'lonely and helpless' atmosphere and proclaims the beginning of a new, multi-layered kind of fun you've never felt in Subnautica before. 

Oh, almost forgot – you can add your own songs, and it's really simple. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2802309020
🐙 All right – time to wrap this one up. For me, Below Zero was able to reignite the spark, returning the wonderful feeling of being lost in an unfamiliar world. I played the original for well over 100 hours, completed it several times with and without mods, and the excitement naturally dwindled; I knew what to expect, what to do, and where to go. Below Zero combined relative familiarity with core gameplay mechanics and a completely different environment; even though it made some mistakes along the way, it accomplished the main goal –  allowing me to go on a brand new adventure once again, and for that I'm thankful.

🦈 P.S. Some particularly nasty individuals can't stop going on about this game being 'woke' because it's got a couple of gay characters and a black female as a protagonist; if you get your panties in a bunch because you see 'propaganda' in a game where someone's sexual orientation is casually mentioned [i]once,[/i] then get on yer little soapbox and speak of your petty frustrations to the world – whatever, everyone is entitled to have an opinion. Just don't be surprised when we laugh at you.

Both Subnautica games are outstanding! Using observation and wit to work around not being at the top of the food chain is an often overlooked element of games that the Subnautica series uses to great effect. 
Makes me long for a Skyrim sized Subnautica game!

Below Zero takes everything that was captivating and amazing about Subnautica and blatantly disregards it in an attempt to break new ground with a new story.  

Every individual component of the game is executed worse than the previous iteration.

The story is the least disappointing part, except for the part where you've already figured out everything about halfway through. There are no surprises, no twists, no turns. Character vignettes are surprisingly well done, and they did a good job making the unseen cast have their presence felt. The decision to voice the protagonist and give them their own spoken narrative... obliterates the storytelling whenever she speaks up. She's not very relatable, and her dialogue is mediocre most of the time. The VA performance is great, from her and the rest of the cast. But it never stops being jarring every time she speaks, and really breaks the feeling of isolation and tension. I want to feel like I'm uncovering something spooky and mysterious, and it's impossible to do that if every time I find something notable, the main character pipes up to give commentary that often doesn't fit the mood of the player at the moment.  

Locations are a nightmare. The world map is broken up in such a way that you find yourself doing mostly "dead-end" journeys. You venture out to an area, and have to go further and further into it until you find what you were looking for, and then retrace your steps methodically to leave. There are few interconnections, most locations only have one way in or out, with tons of dead space between their entrances and where you need to go. You will constantly be backtracking your way out of the same places you've been. Cave networks are more convoluted and devoid of landmarks that make navigation palatable. You can expect to run in circles wondering if you've actually explored the breadth of an area, because the one branch looks identical to the next.  

Creatures are mostly underwhelming. Most of the "enemies" can be safely disregarded, and apart from a few areas, don't guard or patrol anywhere remarkable. The predator creatures are often copy-pasted to ridiculous extents in otherwise empty waters, but can still be avoided simply by going around them. 

Land exploration is like pulling teeth. Journeying through blinding snow is exhausting, as every location looks and feels the same. Land areas are open and repetitive, with few interesting landmarks or terrain to make them unique. You unlock a hoverbike to help you navigate the terrain, but then they make much of the terrain in those areas poorly navigable on the bike. At no point do you have an opportunity to open up the throttle and speed across the glaciers, really making use of the mobility. 

Vehicles are worse than before. Cooler concepts, but after 16 hours I hadn't found enough researched parts to really build out any of the offerings. An upgrade here, an upgrade there. Never really felt like I got to use them beyond just taxi service. The Prawn is completely unused in the game apart from those players who may want to build megabases for fun.  

Overall, if you've played the first one, you can safely leave this aside.

I liked the first Subnautica's storyline better, I felt it was too short. But I enjoyed the new items and creatures in this one! If they brought out a 3rd game that was equally as long and interesting story line as the first one, plus the new items I'd really enjoy that.

Still a good game

Probably a good game if you haven't played the first, but compared to the first, it's a massive disappointment. It feels like a DLC rather than a sequel, and even as a DLC it would've been meh at best. They managed to sort out the pop-in issues for the most part, but other than that, they stripped out everything I loved, and was looking forward to more of, from the first game.

I'm hoping for a sequel, and want more from these devs, but it has to be a thumbs down as I really hope they go back to the cyclops and the focus on the dark, scary depths of the first. No more above land stuff, please!
Loved the original, but this game is pretty weak. Way smaller and shallower map, everything is brightly lit, the predators are a joke and the atmosphere and horror is tuned down to 0.

So there are aspects of it that are better than the first one, but overall, I'd prefer the first one. 

The stuff that is better, than Subnautica:
-> Oxygen plants to extend underwater exploration.
-> Much more varied and wondrous environments and creatures. 
-> New base building components, like domed roof, large rooms, and jukebox to listen to tunes.
-> More surface level exploration

The stuff that is worse:
-> The sea truck. Replaces the Seamoth and Cyclops, and is takes on all of the very worst aspects of each. It is less durable than the Seamoth and consumes power worse than the cyclops. It is less maneuvarable than the cyclops and is weirdly shaped which makes it hard to fit into spots that look fittable, but aren't. I lost 2 Sea Trucks just bumping into random objects, whereas the Sea Moth, despite it being flimsy, held up better than it. Also the Sea truck has almost zero storage space, with lockers that are 3x5 4x5 and 5x6. Standard built lockers are like 6x8. It isn't intuitive on separating from the attached modules and wasn't intuitive in attaching to them.  
-> Less direction. You don't get many nav points in this one, so you'll be told something important is nearby, but not in what direction or if it is above or below you. I had to use guides to find story-specific locations, as I couldn't find them otherwise. 
-> Fewer resources. I was constantly starved for lead and gold, and just could not find enough of it. In Subnautica, you'd have groups of resources types ie copper, titanium, and lead. Now its copper or titanium, lead or titanium, silver or titanium, etc... It is also harder to acquire salt and quartz too for some reason. 
-> Base building underwater felt more restrictive, as the support poles wouldn't attach a lot of the time, making it impossible to place modules otherwise. 
-> The story was lacklustre and the characters weren't interesting.

I ended up quitting the game and giving up. I was trying to find Margerites greenhouse, hit an ice berg, and lost my sea truck again, for a third time, and as I was 1800 meters from my lifepod, I just didn't have the desire to swim back, hunt for lead and gold again, to rebuild the darn sea truck. And like Subnautica, if it is destroyed, all its modules are gone as well. 

I got it for 50% off, so I feel a bit better about that, but having played and enjoyed a lot of Subnautica, I was hoping for more of that here and I was severely disappointed. And the modding community isn't as great so there aren't even mods out there to fix the issues I had. Shame. Guess, I'll have to launch Subnautica again to get my underwater fix.

Huge disappointment after Subnautica.

The story: feels forced and unnatural, and there is no coherent storyline to the actions you have to take to progress through the game. Furthermore, it's very short and there is no satisfying ending. To make matters worse, the game gives you sometimes little to no guidance on where to progress further, it just tries to inflate the otherwise short playtime by forcing you to wander around - on one occasion I had to look up a location online, otherwise I would have literally got stuck at that point.

The map: is too small and uninteresting, and the different biomes are not distinctive enough which makes navigating unnecessarily difficult. This is especially true for the biomes above water, where everything just looks the same. The map size does not even necessitate building a base for the sake of it being more central, which in Subnautica was a lengthy and worthwhile undertaking. Such a shame that they put so much effort into the base assets (much more and nicer than in the original) that you are not required to use.

The animals: do not even come close to the original game. Nothing beats Reaper Leviathans. The scary animals in this game are just not scary, though the penguins are nice.

The tech: feels rehashed and repetitive. Compared with the great vehicles of Subnautica, these feel very badly designed for exploration and are not good at what they do. I miss the Cyclops. The Seatruck is just an absolute oaf, difficult to pilot in tight spaces and you can barely see out of the cockpit, which makes navigating super difficult.

The first Subnautica was great! This is a boring rehash, with additions of more of the bad stuff from the first title. Sure, some interesting biomes and base upgrades. But as a game it just gets tedious, and the story is unengaging.
Just play the original again instead. This one simply doesn't vibe. The quality-of-life improvements are nice, but it's just not as good as the first, especially the music and athmosphere is lacking

I was excited to play this game because I loved the original Subnautica. When I saw it was discounted, I immediately bought it and started playing. I had tons of fun for the first hour and a half, running around collecting materials, finding out some of the story, and even constructing the seatruck. But then I encountered an issue that completely ruined this experience for me. I went to the Delta Base beacon and everything was completely unloaded and I phased right through the ground. I thought, ok thats annoying but I can just reload the game and hopefully it will be there. I then attempted to save the game and then quit, but I was stuck on the saving screen for more than 20 minutes. I finally had to force quit the game to get out of the save bug and I logged back in to see that all of my progress is gone. This is supposed to be a complete game and has been out for over a year now. These kinds of game breaking issues should not still be in the game. Having this happen to me completely ruined the experience for me and I immediately uninstalled the game. Maybe I will pick it up again in a couple months and play it, but how am I supposed to know this won't happen again?
not as good as original and gets boring after like an hour of playing, could not get to end game without getting bored

I think the original Subnautica was a true GOAT, one of the most amazing gaming experiences I've ever had, but Below Zero is unfortunately a pretty solid disappointment. It has a lot of good stuff and I can't fault anyone for liking it, but for me it just didn't live up to what it could have been.

The biggest issue is how cramped and, for lack of a better word, shallow the map felt overall. The addition of the above-ground snow stuff was just terrible and a slog and wasted a lot of development time for a sub-par experience, which could have been spent really giving things breadth. Some of the new biomes were absolutely great, but as a whole, and I don't exactly know how it managed to do this, felt cramped. How an 'underwater' game feels cramped is almost mind boggling in how misjudged it was.

A worse vehicle on top of the mandatory, unfun above ground annoying to navigate snow-worm area - which if you sped fast and jumped with the bike, the snow worm would burst out of the middle of the air to be underneath you, complete with snow debris - took the wind out of the game in a very unpleasant way.

The original worked because of the thalassophobia effect, excellent level and maybe the best sound design in any media ever, much less a video game, that worked in concert with said effect. When there is almost no deep, open water where anything might be lurking, when you can see all the edges in most of the biome areas, you almost always have a visual anchor.. eh. Falls flat.

As someone with thalassophobia, the first game was staggering in immersiveness and almost impossible to play it was so tense. BZ feels very safe and light. The tension and atmosphere and the lurking danger of the dark unknown of Subnautica was a heavy weight that kept you submerged.

I have to rate this game negatively in hopes the devs make another because I would like to see changes.

Basically, Subnautica was/is a complete masterpiece. Absolutely terrifying and wonderful. At the end I just wanted more; bigger levels, more leviathans, more cyclops.

Below Zero does not provide this and the game is weaker for it. I wish the devs had spent less time world building and more time building environment size, leviathan size, and sea truck size. Hopefully there is another game and it goes back to the feeling of the original game

There is no game in the world that had such a great impact on me.

I doubt I can appreciate any other open world game the same anymore. I play games since 1999 and this is by far the best one I've experienced.

It is truly , without a doubt, a masterpiece.

[/i]

[i]Great voice acting, gunfire sounds are mehh I dunno how to explain!

[i]The game runs smoothly on my system, well optimized.
The game uses source engine from valve so don't worry about system requirements!
But try to upgrade your system because the more frame rates, the more fun you will have!
[/i]

-[b]Grind: 7/10[/b]
[i]Nothing special,you will finish the game in a week then you going to play multiplayer or share your screenshots...

-[b]Game Time: 8/10[/b]

-[b]Price: 10/10[/b]
[i]You will not regret it, so add it to your cart right now!

[i]One of the best multiplayer games of all time, but the servers are down!
Gamers miss this game so much...
Poor support by Respawn and EA... they threw it in the corner.[/i]

Total Score: 9.1★

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Titanfall 2 is just fantastic.  A campaign that is more than just an enjoyable adventure, it features constantly evolving mechanics always surprising you with new twists and exciting things to do.  It brings a freshness I haven't seen since Portal 2, while keeping the length at "just about right".

There's genuine effort put into the plot and level design of what could have otherwise been a barebones story thrown in as a tutorial for the multiplayer mode.  Instead, what little I heard of it made me check the game when I had no interest whatsoever in trying its multiplayer aspects.  And I'm glad I got on this ride because it was such a fun romp!

While you can see most of the story outcomes (including the ending) come from a mile away, the moment to moment parts are crafted so well that it won't matter how predictable things are.  Your character goes from low rank infantry trooper to an experienced mech pilot through the many gauntlets the story throw at you, and they are all glorious, memorable set pieces that vary the gameplay just enough, while introducing all sorts of charismatic villains to face off in such clashes.

And through all of that, the bond between the main character and the Titan's self-learning AI (nicknamed BT) grows slowly but noticeably and -- silly as it may seem -- that too becomes a highlight.  From initially addressing the MC as a disposable "Pilot", to "Cooper", and eventually to first name basis "Jack", it's a scene with meaning and heart when BT suddenly turns to the MC and says "trust me" like an actual battle comrade would instead of just silently proceeding with the mission.

On to the gameplay, this too is a standout experience that differentiates Titanfall 2 from other shooters.  With a fluidity and precision that are so seamless, you end up pulling whatever creative moves you can think of.  Wall walking, double jumping, the stealth mode strafing, the absurd selection of weapons available to loot from the different militias (each weapon with its own distinctive feel), it all comes together to form a frantic parkour-infused action package that somehow manages to stay elegant at all times.  And that's you playing as a soldier on the ground!  The moment you embark on your humongous mech, the world changes, the tiny people in the ground trying to shoot are insignificant and only the brutal clashes against other Titans matter.  It's satisfying how those two completely different realities coexist so well together.

All in all, a shame that the likelihood of a sequel of this quality is unlikely to ever appear.

I would 100% recommend this game. After 600 hours I still can't seem to put the game down for long before getting the itch to pick it back up. Even in the current state the Multiplayer is in. I will clarify on that towards the end.

The campaign, while short, is well worth the experience. It comes in around 5-6 hours depending on how well you pick up the mechanics. The level design does an outstanding job of teaching you the game while not getting stale. They introduce a new mechanic, let you play with it, then move on to the next one. This provides a real sense of progression. The story itself is well written in such a way that you feel a connection between BT and Cooper that I have rarely experienced in most other games. There are ups and downs. Laughs and somber moments. Sure some of the characters and set pieces can be cheesy or over the top, but that's gaming and it works for TF|2. Overall my only gripe is that at the end I felt  myself wanting more of the campaign. They took the foundation from TF|1 and really hit it out of the park.

Now for the Multiplayer. I played before, during, and after the hacks/DDOSing that brought the game and community to its collective knees. Before the hacks the game was so much fun. The skill floor and ceiling are high BUT, the community for the most part is super welcoming and willing to help new pilots learn the ropes. I would know as that's how I cut my teeth and learned. This is also how I made some close friends and ended up in some wickedly cracked private lobbies with some of the better known vets in the community, To watch them move through the maps was like watching lightning sear across the sky, The display of skill showed what the games movement mechanics could really do. During the DDOSing attacks, the games were limited as lobbies would be sent back to the menu and matches would crash. I stepped away at the peak of this and came back after a few months to find the game in a quasi playable state. people still played where they could and the community was just happy to play whatever matches they could get into. Games in vanilla TF|2 are still doable but it takes time and a lot of re-entering lobbies. People still play. There is still a community as of writing this.

Then came the Northstar Client. This client made the multiplayer not only usable again, but also better than before. It is easy to download and install. I'm not super tech-savvy and I got it setup to launch the Northstar Client direct from Steam. All of the standard base game modes are there and you can even play the campaign through the Northstar Client. All skins, weapons, attachments, perks, abilities, and even titans are unlocked from the start. Even rare community event skins that you may not have unlocked in the vanilla game. All the original games modes for both Multiplayer and Frontier Defense are available to play as long as you can find a server, then there are the community modded game modes that really make the game fun. Like fast ball or gun game. Prime titans even have new loadouts and weapons like the brute cannon or the grapple hook. Northstar receives a fairly regular regiment of patches that fix bugs and security risks. over all a huge boost to get a game I love back up and playable again. You can try the vanilla Multiplayer, but I would highly recommend the Northstar Client to play the Multiplayer.

So overall I would personally give the game a 9 out of 10. It deserved better treatment than it got and more attention than it did. Hard to say what it would look like today if it had. But for what we have it is still an outstanding game. One that I hope to see continue getting new pilots to the frontier, eager to learn the movement mechanics and have a fun time zooming the maps. Stay safe out there pilots.

We Were Here Forever is the refined crescendo the series has been building up to in past iterations.
The previous games established much of the basic premise and puzzle structures, but were clearly still unrefined and had a lot of things that detracted from the nicer aspects. But We Were Here Forever fixes all of those detractors and more.

This review will not contain spoilers, but if you want a TL'DR; the game is superb and an example of co-operative puzzle games and instantly one of my favorite puzzle games period.
Regardless, time to get into the nitty gritty.

---- Visual & Audio ----

Put simply, I love the design of this world. The art style and level design are not only incredibly beautiful, but incredibly fitting thematically. The world feels simultaneously magical like straight out of a fairytale, but also still makes total sense to navigate and explore. The detail in designs is fantastic and the variety of areas and environments is diverse and at times breathtaking. Visually the game is a master class of using effective design decisions to showcase the story and the world as you navigate it.

Levels are unique and feel refreshing to look at, while the puzzles are integrated organically into the surrounding world. With lighting and use of props the world highlights what it needs to to make navigating intuitive, and also does an effective job of conveying emotion and tension.

The sound design is clear and beautiful. The music of the game is gorgeous, and the voice acting of the characters has no right being as good as it is for a puzzle game. The Jester's voice actor in particular brought their absolute best, and I was continually impressed by their performance in various parts of the game.
If it were up to me, they'd get an award.

The use of cutscenes and animations, while subdued and not excessive, is very effective. And the visual and audio design of those cutscenes is fantastic and truly left an impression on me.
All of this combines into a style that I truly think will stand the test of time and will still inspire joy in people years from now. And all the kudos to the artists and sound designers, as well as the voice cast.

---- Puzzles ----

The puzzles are plentiful, and yet incredibly unique. The puzzles didn't repeat themselves past their welcome, and were always intuitively designed to fit into the environment and to be easily approachable and understandable. As well as requiring you to move around whilst doing so, making it feel more kinetic and memorable than simply staring at a piece of paper or a machine. Offering a nice variety of both difficulty and type of puzzle means that you're not likely to get bored at lack of new things to try or puzzles to figure out. So if you want to be truly tested on various kinds of puzzles, this is the game for you without a doubt.

The communication between co-op partners is intuitive and encourages you to learn to communicate more effectively. The puzzles are designed in a way where you can describe the situation very well once you wrap your head around it, and all it often takes is for your partner to say one thing to set the light bulbs off in your head. In addition to this many levels involve changing around the perspective between you and your partner, as well as converging your paths only to separate them again.
This all makes for a far more organic feeling and free environment, making it feel less constrained and boxed in than previous We Were Here titles, or many other puzzle games.

Communication in-game is done through a simple but effective voice chat system incorporating a walkie talkie. (Though granted I played it with a friend over Discord, but it's nice to have for those that don't have that option or want the extra immersion.) Communication is key, and this is a good way to practice how well you and a friend can sync up and learn to convey information.

The puzzles never got on my nerves, though you might of course be different in this regard, but I was simply enjoying my time far too much. And overall the puzzles are fantastic and deal with so many unique concepts and gameplay methods that I can't help but applaud the developers.

---- Gameplay ----

Playing the game is incredibly intuitive, navigating is easy and straightforward and the game does a fantastic job of introducing the environments and puzzles to you. The tutorial the game begins with is very effective at conveying all the basic skills you'll need to get started, and once the game proper begins it's a steady curve of improvement and challenge from one location to the next.

The gameplay is solid and functions as expected with the exception of a few slight bugs here and there, but nothing game breaking as far as I or my friend experienced. The controls are responsive and the way you interact with the environment or the puzzles are all simple to grasp on a technical level. The levels are designed in a way to make them quite easy to wrap your head around and figure out where everything is, with clever uses of memorable landmarks as well as good use of lines of sight.

This also extends to your partner, and locating each other is usually not too difficult. And if you have trouble figuring out where you are, just describe what you see and turn on your torch and finding each other is quick and easy. The co-op aspect of gameplay works without issues and I encountered no problems that prevented us from progressing during the entire duration of the game. Connection seems a non-issue (though that's to be expected) with the only slight desync happening for some animations.

Overall the game is very accessible even if you're fairly new to first person games, and wrapping your head around the ordeal won't take too long to figure out.

---- Technicals ----

The game runs flawlessly, with one notable exception. Transitions from level to level often cause lag and choppiness for some amount of time as the levels load in. However, it subsides quickly and once the game has finished loading everything in, all problems are gone. Performance is rock solid beyond these load moments, and I had no issues playing the game what-so-ever.

The controls are responsive and the menus are a vast improvement over previous titles in the series, and the UI is well designed and clean allowing you to take everything in properly.
A lot of people kept referring to a bugged puzzle in the graveyard section of the game, but we encountered no bug in said area. Not sure if we simply got lucky, or if there's something else going on. But overall there was no real hindrance at any point to our playthrough or enjoyment, and overall the experience was pretty flawless.

---- Closing thoughts ----

Ultimately it comes down to one simple fact. Do you like puzzles?
If you do, then this game is undoubtedly worth checking out, and a great way to spend some quality time with a friend. However it is worth noting that as a co-op only puzzle game.
I would recommend either bringing along a friend, or finding suitable players on the community page or through other means. Since it definitely is a commitment, albeit a fairly small one.

Overall We Were Here Forever is one of my favorite puzzle games of all time. Up there with games like Portal or Talos Principle. A unique and refreshing experience with beautiful designs throughout, a fantastic style, absolutely stellar voice acting and audio, and some of the most breathtaking and varied environments.

The developers have refined their talent, and have put out a game that truly is one of the best of its kind.
And the amount of love and effort put into every corner of the game is undeniable.

The name of the game is incorrect, since we were only there for a couple evenings. But the game certainly makes a compelling case for why I would want to be there forever. Since it was truly a wonderful experience made with care and love.

And I'd be lying if I said I didn't want much, much more of it.

After my first play through I would rate this a 9.5/10
The game play is truly remarkable! From the puzzles of varying difficulty and length, to the atmospheres that help immerse me into the game, each chapter that was played allowed me to enjoy the game more and more but also helped get the proverbial gears turning in my head for further puzzles.

The only issues I have had so far are sometimes the walkie-talkies would stop working for an entire chapter (restarting would fix) and in the last portion of the game, there is a animation to get up ladders which was kinda buggy but other than those two small bugs, smooth sailing.

It's a great coop only game. It's longer than any of the previous games in the series (took us 11hrs to do first run), and the quality is higher. Puzzles are varied and never too difficult. There does appear to be a way to find people to play with, but I would highly recommend grabbing a friend.

I do have some criticisms:
* The game forced us to accept an EULA. I don't know why that is necessary. Because it shouldn't be.
* The game has an account system - god knows why, but at least it's optional.
* Performance is certain parts, most notably the underwater part is quite bad
* Some of the puzzles require one of the players to do majority of the thinking while the other player got not  much to do, which kinda is a problem
* We had some connection issues mid game, where my friend simply could not connect to their proprietary servers. It would appear the game does not support Steam P2P and requires some bullshit online servers. What happens when the developer decides to shut them down?
* The potion puzzle having a time limit is anti fun.
* There are some inconsistencies in quality. Some loading screens are "live" where the game still has things happening, but most of the time it's a black screen. Another one that jumps out is the Rockbury cart ride, where certain things are clearly not animated when they should be. Certain interactions are not animated in 3rd person such as pushing revolving lever things. In most cases when you interact you cannot look around to see if your partner is fucking around or not.

[b]The Dead End[/b] is a dungeon survival game(dungeon crawler) where you explore a cursed dungeon, the Labyrinth of Undeath, and rescue those trapped inside! In [b]The Dead End[/b] You take on the role of a rescuer(salvager), who saves people who become trapped in the cursed dungeon, where those who lose all strength turn into zombies. You must manage your resources, maintain your food and water levels, fend off monsters, and delve into its deepest depths.

The survivors can be rescued for consensual sex, raped, or discarded and zombified. Some enemies and monster girls can be raped after defeat, sold to a brothel, or kept in your own dungeon.

Present in the game are 5 main female characters (priestesses and knights), as well as many side characters.

[h1][u]Gameplay[/u][/h1]
[b]The Dead End[/b] is another great game by the man himself [b][u][url=https://twitter.com/c_osanagokoro]Osanagokoro no Kimi ni[/url][/u][/b], this time it's a dungeon crawler style RPGM game.
While carelessly exploring and roaming throughout the dungeon, you'll find the girls that have been trapped within, giving you 3 options that are replayable; Love, slave or zombie.

[b][u]Game Is:[/u][/b] Ero RPG dungeon-crawler with a strong focus on time-management.

[b][u]Important:[/u][/b] The H-tags associated with this game can be a bit more intense than some other eroges. If you generally prefer softer tags then this may not be for you.

[hr][/hr]
[b][u]Tích cực/Negative Thoughts[/u][/b]

+   The art of the H-content is decently okay but the scene animations are quite well done and where the game really shines.

+   The time system and how it affects the H-content is probably the big unique selling point but the game is a bit vague on how it works. The conditions of the characters and their later H-scenes have quite a few states that will be progressed through based on how long it takes you to finally reach them in the dungeon.

+   The H-content settings have a surprising amount of customization that let you tailor the experience to best suit you.

+/-   The dungeon-crawling is pretty okay, the survival mechanics are kinda basic but do the job of keeping pressure on you while exploring. You get a variety of new traversal items throughout the game which help keep things interesting.

-   The combat can be pretty clunky and makes certain encounters especially frustrating.

[hr][/hr]
[b][u]In Summary:[/u][/b] A clunky dungeon-crawler that has surprisingly well done H-scene animations and an interesting time-system that gives the H-content a unique twist.

[b][u]Tip:[/u][/b] Press F4 to toggle fullscreen.

[h1]10,000,000 Zombies vs. 50,000 WW2 Soldiers[/h1]
I wanted to see how many units the engine could handle, so I threw a truly outrageous amount of zombies into it. The map loaded up. All of the units appeared. My FPS was hovering around 4. Totally unplayable. To its credit, it warned me it would be unplayable with that many units and even better is it DID actually load and run. So i quit and lowered the number of zombies to a more reasonable amount.

5,000,000 Zombies vs. 50,000 WW2 Soldiers:
Wow. Not only did this run, but it ran fairly well. Absolutely playable, so here's how it went:
I picked the map with the river with multiple bridges. Massive (that's 5 MILLION) zombie horde on one side, 50,000 WW2 soldiers on the other, placed 5,000 at a time at each bridge.
The game loaded relatively quick and I pressed the button to start the battle. The zombies started splitting off and heading towards the nearest foes, as did the soldiers. The problem here is that some of the zombies were far enough away that the soldiers crossed one of the bridges to attack, losing their strategic advantage.

The AI is fairly simple. Units will head for the shortest route to their enemies, and then stand in a massive blob waiting to attack. Nothing too exciting, but it works well enough for hordes of zombies.

I let the game run on its own for a while, and when I came back I found that the zombies had (unsurprisingly) massacred the soldiers that had crossed the bridge and were now slowly streaming their way up to the other bridges, which were still holding just fine. It seemed that a relatively small force could hold off the zombies at a bridge, especially since they don't swim. This is when I decided to take action and use what I think is one of this game's strongest features. RTS Mode.

I peeled off a small company of soldiers from a bridge that was being held just fine and started marching them down towards the zombies that had made it through. I split the force into 2 groups and slowly worked them up towards the bridge, one group moving while the other covered it. In a few minutes I had retaken the bridge. I made sure to issue an order for them to hold the position, and I left them to defend. Turning my attention to the rest of the battlefield, I found that some other soldiers were pushing too aggressively. They had pushed the zombies across the bridge and followed, but if they attracted too many zombies they would get overrun and another bridge would be open for the zombies to attack. I quickly grabbed some units from another nearby bridge and had them fire on the zombies while I pulled the squad back across the bridge to hold that position. Perfect. All bridges covered, no zombies advancing. At this point, I had lost nearly half of my units, while the zombies still numbered in the millions.

After some waiting, I noticed that some areas were thinning out the zombies, so I decided to go on the offensive. I grouped up some units from these bridges while leaving some to defend just in case, and began advancing on the flanks of the zombies, which were now split into two giant groups on either side of the map. I slowly advanced the soldiers, and as they did more and more zombies would peel off from the groups at the bridges and come to attack my offensive line. Not enough though. I was able to slowly work through this group of over a million zombies and clear out this one side of the map. 

At this point, the mountains of zombie corpses were so high by the bridges still defending that I was worried the zombies would be able to cross the river, which was now red. The entire landscape had been coated in blood. Low spots had practically formed new rivers that fed into each other. The landscape was being transformed with corpses and blood.

Once I cleared out the top half of the map, I issued an order for all the units up there to start marching on the lower half. It was only a matter of time before the zombies were wiped out, and they were. The last bridge to be cleared of zombies was the one that had originally been overtaken. It had held out this entire time with the handful of units I had left there. Finally, the last few zombies were picked off and I achieved victory.

Now, I could have just left the game alone once I retook the bridge that had been overrun, and I probably would have won just the same. However, being able to take control of these massive numbers of units and take the fight to the overwhelming opposition and WIN? That's awesome. I played the original game a bit, but found it a bit dull after doing a few battles. Placing down a couple blobs of units and watching them run into each other for a while can only be fun for so long.

In this game I was worried that it would suffer from the same issue, just on a MUCH larger scale. RTS mode removes that worry. The game is still pretty slim on content, but what has been achieved with this new engine... It's hard to really even put into words how it feels to see that many units on screen and have the game perform anywhere near acceptably. More than that, to actually be able to issue commands to the units and have them (mostly) follow those orders? Wow.

The engine is an incredible achievement, and the actual gameplay makes me excited for where they could take this. RTS mode is the thing that brings what could be another dull unit blob-fest up to another level, and I hope that the developers continue to expand on it. Could we see this turn into a full-fledged RTS? I hope so. If not, there's still some great content here for battle simulations on a truly epic scale.
