Since I know for me and maybe some other people who have lower end PCs, the ability to really make some of these battles epic was a concern.  So i ran my computer through what it could really do.  I didn't get into the exact number of units that I tried out but as the numbers got higher I made it a more general unit amount.  Anyway, to start, here is what I am running off of....

MSI GF65
i7-10750H CPU @ 2.60GHz
32gb DDR4 2666
1660ti w/ 6gb 
1tb kingston boot drive
1tb samsung evo ("steam drive")
(quick edits - by saying "seamless below I mean no frame drops and also my graphics settings were set at mid-range with everything set to "High")

I figured that units that used projectiles would probably be the ones that use the most and this turned out to be correct.  What I topped out at in this aspect was 1.5million vs 1.5million archers.  This game a seamless performance. I wasn't able to get the game itself to crash when I did higher amounts but to be honest I wasn't patient enough to let it run itself down to a more seamless unit total.

As far as non-projectile units I was able to keep a smooth 2.5million vs 2.5million foot soldiers.  Again, I tried the higher numbers without a crash and I did not wait for it to wear down to a more stable amount.

Let me preface this by saying I never played UEBS 1 so if I mention something that was also in that game...oh well!

There are a few pretty cool things about this game other than its performance.  When large amounts of units are killed their blood will run in the natural channels of the landscape.  You don't actually see it flow so much as it is like watching a towel soak up something wet if that makes sense.  There a several units to choose from but even at that, you can use existing models and customize their stats and names and make them whatever you want.  Its pretty cool.

The ability to watch it play out, play a single soldier, or control several troops at once is pretty cool as well.  

The loading screens and the menus are a bit rudimentary but I see two reasons why this shouldn't matter.  First of all, it is early access and we can't expect a spit polish on this and second...lets be honest....who buys this game for the menus  Its not Ultimate Epic Menu Simulator now is it?

TL:DR  The dev hardware/performance stats in the discussions seem to be pretty close if not slightly underrated (but in my opinion that is better than overrated!) and it is a great game to play!

Overall I enjoy the concept of the game, and this is definitely better optimised than the first game allowing much larger battles. However at time of writing this review there isn't really enough content to make buying this game worth it, which is the same problem that the first game had.

That being said, I understand that the game is currently early access and will have more added over time, so i'll consider coming back to this game once it's out of early access, then update my review if necessary

reviews.developer_response: Try to understand that we are working as fast as we can.  The current Alpha build contains 19 unique units, which is more than UEBS1 had at launch.  Another thing to keep in mind is, a great deal more work goes into new units compared to the first one.  Most of characters in UEBS2 are modelled in house, where as UEBS1 characters are all from 3rd party sellers such as the Unity asset store.  Many new characters also have unique abilities as well, which requires custom coding.

reviews.developer_response:
Hey there!
Thanks for giving the DLC a fair shot.

The thing with big enclosures is the fact that today, the standards of animal enclosures are really lackluster, and in many cases, people keep their pets in enclosures that are too small for them.
We made sure to work with experienced caretakers and various pet communities in order to create an example of perfect animal conditions, even though we're still working on things like properly keeping herd animals in pairs at least, as we had some technical difficulties with that.

When it comes to bugs, over the weekend we've already released 2 hotfixes that removed a few minor ones. Over the course of next week, we will be releasing more of those in order to patch any issues that popped out after the release, as well as tweak the animal behavior.
If I may ask, please let us know about any issues you encountered through [url=https://frozendistrict.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/HFS/pages/2847277075/House+Flipper+-+Support+Tickets]our support ticket platform[/url], so we can take care of them asap.

Have a great day!
- Reczberg

reviews.review:
I'm going to start with a warning: this game has a lot of reading and you HAVE to read it or else nothing will make sense, so if you tend to skip dialogue or reading lore in games, this isn't for you. There is an option to change all the handwritten fonts to something more legible, but I'm not dyslexic, so I can't say if that font is dyslexic friendly. However, if you love reading, solving mysteries, identifying plants, and spooky, but not too spooky, aesthetics, buy this, you will adore it!

Visually it reminds me of Sunless Sea, and the gameplay is somewhat reminiscent of mystery point and click games. The writing is brilliantly done, very atmospheric. I loved the story, it's very folkloric and references old witchcraft/pagan rituals. One complaint, if you can even call it that, I had to force myself to take breaks, otherwise I would have played it until I completed it in one sitting. But despite a short playtime, it's got multiple choices and therefore multiple endings, so there's more than one playthrough awaiting me. 

I enjoyed the gameplay. I'm not going to spoil anything, so my review of the gameplay is going to be a bit vague here. I love mystery games that don't make it super easy to solve stuff or give you the same "one of us tells the truth" riddle to solve, or the "play the piano" puzzle that seems to be in every mystery game. I'm not a huge fan of hidden object games because the puzzles feel so random, like you're tracking a serial killer, but suddenly there's a word search, and it ruins my immersion. This game DOESN'T do that, and I am so glad. Every puzzle/riddle feels story relevant and makes me feel fully immersed. This game made me feel smart, and at times, kind of dumb, which is why I play these games! I also played a bit with my partner helping and I think if you're looking for a mystery game to play with a partner, this would be a really good choice! We had fun.

It's a simple concept, but executed perfectly. I highly recommend this game to anyone who loves solving riddles, and lovers of the mystery genre in general.

Also any game that lets you pet your cat is amazing.
I have a black cat, my own plant store, and I get to solve a cool witchy mystery. I'm sold

I enjoyed this game very much. Identifying the plants using the deliberately incomplete information was a fun challenge, but not so difficult that I couldn't work things out with some careful thought and comparison. The vibe of the game and the writing style reminds me of Fallen London, which I loved. The mystery that unfolds was intriguing too, and I liked that there were several different endings to explore. I think it speaks well of the game that I wished it was a bit longer, with more of the plant-finding, identification and elixir-making etc. For me, that shows how much fun those things were for me. Would love to see the game expanded in some way, but I am also genuinely very happy and impressed with it as it is.

Amazing, wonderful, spooky, and most importantly: taught me about horticulture! I had no idea that identifying plants was such a neat process. Plants have so many cool unique features! Worth it!

But it does entertain. 6/10

As much as I think that this is a cool and charming game I don't think it's worth that price, maybe 10€ would be more correct imo (currently it costs 13.5€)

It's technically a rather simple game in the way it works, most puzzles you have to solve work the exact same way, the game is rather short if you know what you're doing and don't get stuck on one or two requests that have rather unclear hints, and the biggest issue I think is that that the game always plays the same : someone comes in the shop and asks for a plant which you have to identify, then it sits on your shelf for the whole game being completely useless except for 3 potions you have to craft in order to complete the game (there are 4 in total if you keep playing afterwards to complete every identification). Not to mention every day will be the same in every playthrough except for a few clients so it basically has no replayability once you've finished it once.

Overall it feels like the plants are simultaneously the core part of the game but also rather worthless since 80% of them have no use outside of being identified and given to the person asking for it (and some will never even get requested), so I don't know if this game will ever get more things added to it but I'd like for plants to have more uses (more potions perhaps) other than sitting in my shop with the game screwing up my organization every time I collect a new one.
Really enjoyable short game (I finished within 7 hours)! I came for the plant identification, and stayed for the intriguing story and purring cat.

Just from the promotional images / videos, I wouldn't have expected to like Strange Horticulture, but once I tried its demo, I was won over nearly instantly. Strange Horticulture has a great sense of atmosphere, from its almost tactile-seeming gameplay and wonderful sound design (both the ambient sounds of the weather and the sound effects for picking up / putting away each item) to its gently spooky town inhabitants and mystery plot.

The developers clearly put a lot of thought and effort into this game, and I really appreciate how even small details serve to flesh out the world, characters, or atmosphere (like how there seems to be no real "game over", just a series of ominous puzzles to solve, or how you can tell that one of the characters has been consuming a lot of Drathium just by looking at their character portrait - even before you read their bio or talk to them). I also really enjoyed the drip-feeding of the story and puzzles for each day, which gives the game a really nice, consistent pace, as well as the brilliant use of the map - using it for puzzles while also giving a sense of where characters / events are located. All in all, this was a great game and is highly recommended!

This game was relaxing and engaging. The puzzles were not too hard, but a few plants were tricky to identify. I love the cat, of course! I was glad it didn't have time limits - it kept everything cruisy. It's just a nice, enjoyable game. I think my teenage daughter will enjoy it too.

Interesting setting and great artwork. The "puzzles', however, are just making sure you have basic literacy skills. You simply read the entry on the plant and match it to the one on your shelf. As long as you go to the locations in letters and cards, you'll always have the correct plant. I played through five or six days and the formula never increased in difficulty or really changed. It just wasn't challenging enough for my personal taste. Story wasn't compelling enough for me to keep playing.

First playthrough took 5-6 hours. The second one (with a different ending) is now at 8. Atmosphere, Art, Gameplay are pretty interesting and refreshing. However, length is a bit short for me personally. 

The puzzle/detective aspects are either you get it (easy) or you dont (cryptic) side.  And having played various puzzle games like Talos Principle, The Witness, all the Zachtronic ones, most of the puzzles here are fairly straightforward. Except for one which i had to search up (which indicates bad puzzle design). For those other games that i mentioned, i never felt like i had to search anything up; those were more of type where eventually you will solve it so long as you keep at it.

Overall this game is meh, and i would only get it on a sale.
Can pet the cat! She even purrs. 11/10

Good game, good writing and atmosphere.
I was ready to be done by the time I was done; it got to be a little much to try to manage all the details by the very end, but a worthwhile experience.
The narrator of the trailer is amazing and really captures the mood of the game - it's too bad there isn't any actual narration in the game itself.
Why I love Strange Horticulture: the moody 1800s countryside aesthetic; the soothing fun of sorting your growing plant collection; the supernatural murder mystery of it all; petting the shop cat.
May be one of the best games in my 31 years of life I have ever had

God of War was one of my favorite series growing up, and this does not disappoint. Graphics, combat, voice acting, music, plot, all appeal to me and maintain the epic grandeur that characterize god of war stories. They also manage to understand what people want in a god of war game, and fill it with side quests and collectibles that are actually fun and cool to do...the side quests are what make this game special honestly, and the best moments are found while exploring the world. The one thing this game doesn't do as well as the others is boss fights. I felt that the boss fights were a bit lackluster, but admittedly I am comparing this to the other god of war games, which arguably have the best boss fights of any action adventure game. Compared to any other game, these boss fights are incredible, compared to the other god of war games, they are a bit unsatisfying. If you like action, adventure, combat orientated, open world games, this is obviously a game you must play regardless of reviews. One of the best games of its genre ever made.
So thankful that Sony allowed this title to come to Steam. Hopefully more PlayStation exclusives come to Steam.

This is a challenging environmental puzzle game with minimal frills. There is a small hub world that connects to 5 puzzle worlds, each with a different theme. The game is not exactly open world - you have to complete a portion of each level in sequence to open up the next level. But it is usually less than half of each world, and the second half is much harder and sometimes inaccessible until later.

The puzzles range from "not too difficult but still requires some thought" to "real head-scratcher", and the difficulty ramps up nicely. There is no explanation or tutorial for the puzzle mechanics, you just have to try things out and pay attention to your surroundings to figure out how things work. It seems like most of the puzzles are designed so that you cannot just brute force your way though, you have to understand the mechanics for each puzzle. You will need pencil and paper for some puzzles, and screenshots are often helpful as well.

I haven't beaten the game yet (I'm stuck looking for one solution [spoiler]that I suspect will open up some new puzzles[/spoiler]) but I've enjoyed my time so far.

Pros:
[list]
 [*]Good puzzle design and variety of puzzle mechanics. Not a lot of repetition. Lots of "aha moments"
 [*]It feels like The Witness, but less pretentious
 [*]Runs smoothly, and I haven't noticed any issues.
[/list]

Mixed:
[list]
 [*]Not super long, I expect it might take 10-12 hours based on my current progress. But I'd rather have a shorter puzzle game with good puzzles than a long puzzle game full of easy or repetitive puzzles.
 [*][strike]One of the mechanics in the [spoiler]water area with the red green and purple blocks[/spoiler] was really complicated and I'm not sure if there was a better way to solve it other than [spoiler]essentially brute forcing it by keeping notes for each combination[/spoiler].[/strike] EDIT: apparently I am just impatient and [spoiler]this puzzle doesn't require any brute forcing[/spoiler]:D
[/list]

As someone who isn't very big on JRPG's, this one won me over. As the store page promises, it trims the crappy parts that the genre tends to build, namely the need to not grind which is pretty great. If you do push out to grind, it won't be for very long, enemies drop generous amounts of gold (almost overindulgent amounts near the tail end of the game).

 The story is paced fairly well, but I wish it had more complexity. The Humans you fight basically thrive on traditional Saturday morning bad guy shit with no possible redemption, while you happen to be the bad guys next door except your smarter than them, a victim to their bullshit, and also a pretty cute Drow Waifu.
It helps that the English localisation is clear and well done (I saw like 1 spelling error).

The big issue is that it ends VERY quickly (right as things get interesting). Its unfortunate since everything up to the very sudden end was pretty good. You can probably power through this game and still qualify for steams 2hr< refund window if you know where to go. For what it's worth, they did include NG+ options if you want more replay.

This game is thankfully reasonably priced, though you'll get better value when its on sale. I'm curious to see what the follow-up chapters are like.

Looks great, but it's not quite what you expect. It's pretty much a visual novel with some simple fights between scenes, but you can pick which fights/scenes you want to play at any time. There's not a whole lot of fights either, and the enemy states what they're doing before they do it, you just have to plan out your moves based on that.

Overall very short, maybe 30-60 minutes long if you don't make a ton of mistakes. For it's price I don't think the content adds up, so I can't recommend it on full price or light sale, but on a big sale sure. Not that it's bad, it's just way too short. I spent longer downloading it than actually playing it.

On the DLC/Patch side, not a whole lot there either.  Good quality, but only a few stills worth.

Overlord: "Hey Vassals we're gonna tax you more."
[b]- Overlord modifies contract to increase resource tax by 15%[/b]
Vassals: "No thank you."
[b]- Contract denied[/b]
Overlord: "Uh... I'm you're overlord, you gotta do what I say."
[b]- Overlord modifies contract to increase resource tax by 15%[/b]
Vassals: "Nah we don't agree."
[b]- Contract denied[/b]
Overlord: "Well screw you then, we're just gonna annex you."
[b]- Overlord modifies contract so annexation is allowed[/b]
[b]- Contract denied[/b]
Overlord: "Screw this! I'm just gonna do it the old fashioned way.
[b]- Vassals are released, 10 year truce signed[/b]
Overlord: "Oh come on!"
[b]- Truce ends and overlord easily beats old vassals[/b]
Overlord: "Finally! Now I can-"
[b]- Threat of a revolt emerges[/b]
Overlord: "Pfffft, I got ten armies on the planet and a massive fleet in orbit. No way in hell they succeed-"
[b]- Revolt autosucceeds, Old vassals takes half of empire and signs a 10-year truce without a shot fired[/b]
Overlord: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eyK7T-7vCro&ab_channel=Shmayd

You're a vassal. I've beaten you so thoroughly I could've purged your entire species from the galaxy, ending your empire in a mass-extinction. 

But you get to say no if I'm demanding too much from you, and there's nothing I can do about it?
At that point, why not just purge the empire and be done with it? Why is there no system in place to exert my will and power over this tiny inept empire for the terms I demand? 

Whoever designed this really didn't think it through. Forcing your will on vassals is near-impossible because they magically get the right to say no to anything you, the person capable of ending their existence in a second, propose.

I invaded primitives - a bunch of steam age idiots. Placed troops on the planet and built a fort. The planet started a "SITUATION" to revolt. "Okay," I said to myself, "who cares if they revolt - I'll just beat them again." 

WHEN THE SITUATION POPS THEY TAKE MY WHOLE EMPIRE WITH THEM, TAKE MY TROOPS STATIONED ON THEIR PLANETS. NO FIGHT - NO NOTHING. THEY INSTANTLY WIN AND GET A TRUCE. THEY HAVE NO FLEET. 

It was a death spiral of the worst kind. The situation system has these checkpoints in which slap on stronger and stronger debuffs. For the revolt - it's a STACKING stability loss. How are players supposed to dig their way out of this? Why can't the player fight back with - I don't know... their armies? In what universe does an Empire give up half its domain because some RECENTLY BULLDOZED primitives just kinda declared independence?

In my mind, I see it going something like this:

“My Emperor! Dire news from the recently acquired colony!”

“What is it?”

“They’ve successfully passed 1000 signatures on change org petition and have declared themselves independent! What should we do, my Emperor?”

“Firstly, immediately disband all the troops. Then give them half the territory of the empire. No… give them all of it. It’s only fair. After that, tell the fleet stationed there to run off in random directions and get hopelessly lost.”

“Brilliant idea, my Emperor. Anything else?”

“Give them a 10-year truce as well. I mean, what would others think of us if we didn’t give them time to build up...?”

Literally. What is this situation system? Are you kidding me paradox? This is the best you could do?

Edit: Also, these "revolt" nations that get spat out get free 10k resources in minerals, energy, and even alloys. Good luck after 10 years in the early game! :)

There's a situation where several planets will be allowed to secede from your empire with like zero consequences (they get a 10 year truce). You can prevent it by landing troops and building forts but if you don't then you lose like 6 systems without a fight.

So my fanatically loyal troops just decided to lay down their weapons and surrender instantly? Then my emperor just went "oh well, it's not like we have a fleet and an army" and signed the 'recognize these random assholes' accord? What?

This was absolutely terrible game design.

Finally, the MAIN mechanic of the DLC is bad. Vassals get to basically decide 100% of the terms as befits them. Even when you forcibly vassalize someone, the default agreement doesn't include anything but a war agreement and the ability to annex them.

Again, did my militarist empire just go "Well attacking you was super mean so I guess you get to dictate the terms of your subjugation"?

Please fix this. This is genuinely the first DLC I've ever disliked on this game.

So....in DLC all about being an all-powerful overlord and exerting your influence over others through force, which genius at the development studio actually designed the vassal system? Because it is clear they have no idea how vassals work. Vassals don't get to CHOOSE to say yes or no. There is no negotiating with a vassal, that's the point. I've tried to use this system three times now for completely no result. Not a single empire that I subjugate is willing to switch to a specialist vassal. And it is a real slap in the face when you go through the entire process of battling it out with an equal opponent in the early game (the point where vassals would be the most useful), defeating them, and then watching as your demand that they become your research department is met with "This agreement is of no value to us" even after offering them literally every concession available. This is not diplomacy, this is not intended to be diplomacy, this is a military concept and it should be employed like one. Don't call it overlord and then force us to beg OUR vassals to do what we want. I give this a 5-10 until I get to see the new mega-structures.

This is a no until the revolt mechanic gets uhhhhh TONED DOWN A BIT.

Basically if a planet gets to low stability it gets a revolt meter which when it fills up, caus\ing them to grab 2 neighboring systems and make their own empire.

The problem is, there is zero counter play. Unless the stability is a policy problem (or possibly by resettling all the pops) there's no action you can take that'll fix the problem in time. The meter goes to like 100 and can go up by 3-5 each month.

You also have to wait out a truce period to re-invade. And when you re-invade there's no guarantee they won't just revolt again a month later.

Tone it down. Cap it a like 1 or 2 a month and give me options for fixing it (even temporary ones that cost something).

Don't waste your time with this DLC until they fix the absolute horrendous situation system and revolt system. If you conquer a planet, good luck keeping it. I invade a primitive civilization and no matter what I do, they still overthrow me and declare independence. I have tons of armies on the planet, my fleet in orbit and a starbase and I am building on the planet as fast as I possibly can to turn the situation around and no matter what I do, they always revolt. Oh and when they declare independence, they gain that system and any adjacent systems and you cannot attack them for 10 years.

The situation system is a losing game. Each tier of the revolt stacks a negative stability to your planet. How do you possibly fight this when you are given so little time? Honestly... The time it takes for your planet to fully revolt is just beyond a joke. Who play tested this update and said this was okay? If I could refund I honestly would. I just deleted my last save, closed the game and won't be playing again until the fix this mess. It's just absurd. There is absolutely no way to fight the revolt since the negative stability from each tier sets back ANY progress you make in fighting it, and each tier only takes like 500 or so in game days to complete, so you get time to build maybe a single building or district in the time it takes to go up a tier.

The actual overlord mechanics are also terrible. Want to propose terms to your vassals? They can say no... haha? How can someone you subjugated say no to you? Like bruh, I conquered you... You do as I tell you to, not the other way around. Terrible thought out systems that just do not seem like they were tested correctly.

Played a Ravenous Hive. Conquered someone's homeworld who started out with a vassal so had to fight twice the fleet right off the bat but whatever. Turns out its a Doomsday world. Fantastic. Habitability is in the gutter, everyone hates it there. Figures that doesn't really matter cause I'll eat them anyway.

Get an event that tells me rebel forces are organizing. I move a few pops to other planets to manage it. 

"6 months until the event will be resolved." 

Fucking hell, wasn't that at least a year a second ago? Guess I'll have to move more pops out.

"2 months until the event will be resolved."

What the fuck, really? God damn, I could have sworn I had it paused. Alright, time to get everyone off the planet then.

Event pops up, the world goes independent, I lose an additional piece of territory and get cut off from the galaxy. 10 year truce with the newly created empire.

I'm a ravenous swarm. The people I just conquered and ate decided they didn't like it so they left and there was fuck all I could do about it and apparently all of my options to try and combat the situation only accelerate it.

I'll think about changing my review once they fix this, but this really just is a bad joke.

Do NOT buy this DLC - Yet.

The released DLC comes with a plethora of bugs - the monthly trade system is broken, vassals can end up on random sides in a war, and you can even end up in a war versus yourself! And in the peace you can receive the wrong systems. And you can get a situation requiring you to go positive in monthly production of a resource you cannot produce, nor buy on the open market  making you end up in a deathspiral. You'd think that it could be remedied via a monthly trade deal but no. The monthly trade system is completely broken, so anytime you make a trade deal, the AI accepts it, and then immediately cancels it.

There are also a number of balancing issues - like the fact that the balance between what you give a vassal and what you receive from a vassal is skewed by a factor of 10, making many DLC features completely unattainable.

So don't buy this DLC until it is 50% off and they fix the most glaring bugs.

---------------------End of review - Beginning of rant:--------------------------------

Sadly, since we've seen from the example of the "intelligence" system, we can not expect the actual content and balance to ever be fixed - Envoys without levels or traits - and the most useless espionage system ever in a game - I'm looking at you.

It is such a shame that Paradox does this over and over - create the foundation for a great DLC - but never finishes it. Stellaris could have been Stellar! 
But instead it flounders at treetop level and I find myself contemplating going back to master of Orion 2.
What saves Stellaris is the fantastic mods. 
Without the modding community I would have given up on this game years ago. 

If Stellaris was a house you contracted Paradox to build, you'd be surprised when Paradox only delivered the buildings foundation - If you want running water, electricity, windows, doors, a roof that does not leak or any of the other things that makes a building habitable - You will find it at the workshop, not in any Paradox DLC.

Yes, I'm harsh, but this is years of frustration pouring out - Stellaris have added some great features in their DLC's too - But they're always, always lacking.
Add to that the clunky interface that has been in dire need of an overhaul for years now - the endgame lag - the bugs that never gets fixed, the cookie-cutter ship build etc. etc. and I'm beginning to feel like I've been tricked into paying to playtest a product that will never reach the market.

Everyone complaining about the new revolt situation should probably re-read the situation. Landing assault army's and stationing your fleet above a planet has NEVER increased stability, and doesn't work here either. Once you know how to deal with it, it's easy.

>Revolt situation fires
>Click on it
>Click the institute crackdown option - it tells you that stronghold / fortress build speed is increased, probably a clue about how to handle this...
>Find offending planet, go to decisions
>Institute marshal law, and crime lord deal if really desperate
>Build one or two strongholds (more if needed / heavily populated planet), make sure the main species on this planet can take solider jobs
>Suddenly the revolt situation starts to reverse
>Situation ends

Granted, it's not worded very well, but if you know the game mechanics, its easy to solve. Paradox should definitely make it a bit clearer that things like assault army's and fleets do not help here, or maybe change it so they do. As for the vassal stuff and imperial fief exploit, yes these things definitely need to be fixed, but it's Paradox, they normally do fix these things relatively quickly. Overall, solid expansion, will be very nice once the bugs are ironed out.

Adds two new ways to get around the galaxy faster, so if that is something you felt was missing from the game this is for you. New specialized vassals makes them worth it again. Also adds 5 new origins for more flavor in your games. $20 might be a little steep though.

The systems they showed off had a lot of potential to be really cool... but they're half-baked and clearly unfinished.  The new vassal system completely strips any power from the Overlord as vassals can just, say no to everything?  And even if you invade, they can just say "no" and reconquer their system AND some of your territory without doing anything.  And this is if you can even get there!
Just in the first game I played, I ran into:
An AI spawned directly on the border of a militant isolationist fallen empire, who then proceeded to declare war on them every 10 years like clockwork.  This is because the AI's home system was directly next to the FE's territory, and they couldn't dismantle the starbase since, y'know, their homeworld was there.  FE wars only end with humiliation and I think they're prevented from blowing up homeworlds, so they could never force the AI into a position where they wouldn't be angering the FE just by existing.
I, a lithoid empire, received some refugees from a neighboring empire.  Because they eat food and I don't produce any food at all, I immediately got the "you're out of food!" event.  Because I didn't feel like wasting any district slots and jobs to produce food, I just set the refugees as undesirables and expelled them somewhere else.  As soon as they were gone, I stopped having a drain on food I didn't have, and the shortage event stopped progressing.  However... it only goes down if you start producing a surplus of food.  So I can't get rid of it, ever, without wasting resources and jobs producing food JUST to get rid of this event.  So I go to buy some food instead and... you can't buy resources you aren't producing or consuming.  And this leads me into...
The issue where it's impossible to create trade deals with other empires now.  I find an empire that's amicable and offer to trade 1 alloy per month for 1 food per month for 10 years, they agree and the deal goes through.  However, it immediately gets canceled because "our trade deal has ended because the subjugation agreement was canceled," despite... there not BEING any subjugation agreement.  This happened no matter what I tried to trade, or who I tried to trade with.  So I'm just stuck with this food shortage event that isn't causing any actual problems, just taking up screen space.  Whatever.
And then I boot the game up today and it's completely corrupted.  No galaxy map, no resources, no assets, no nothing.  I have literally never had a save corrupt in Stellaris before now.

Absolutely do not recommend, wait until they hotfix this into a playable state.  Absolutely inexcusable.

I have to agree with the majority of the negative comments. Vassals have way too much power over their overlords with this DLC. I have heard arguments that "vassals are not slaves, so this system is realistic!" but that's BS. Have you ever played any other paradox game or looked back at vassal relationships in actual history? Feudal lords always had the option to squeeze their vassals for more than they were willing to give. That comes with inherent risks obviously, but there is literally already a loyalty system included with this update. Why can't I set the terms of my vassals arrangement and the risk be that if I try to take too much from them that they will give me an ultimatum for better terms and if I refuse revolt or ally with another empire to take me down. In my experience it is literally impossible to set some terms. I want 15% research from a vassal so I am slapped with a -500 negotiation penalty for changing terms and a separate -450 penalty for the terms themselves meaning that even if I offered 75% of all of my other resources as subsidies it wouldn't matter and they wouldn't accept it. This makes it so that I do not even want to use the system I just got done spending $20 on. I certainly don't feel like an overlord when I am forced to keep my vassals happy and get next to nothing out of it. It essentially becomes a forced military alliance at best most of the time and nothing else. The core concept is great and I was excited for the update, but this was just a horrible execution. I think in the first video I saw about this update one of the paradox devs said about the DLC "[They] didn't want vassalization to be an extended game over while you waited to be integrated" so they did all of this. That should have been a red flag I suppose, but if you look at it from that angle it makes more sense. This update makes it more fun to be a vassal but certainly doesn't make me want to be an overlord.

EDIT: As of May 16, the stellaris devs announced a hotfix for some of the really pressing problems concerning vassal management I mention below. // 

[b]Hello fellow star travellers, interstellar dicators and galactic republics![/b] I have played Stellaris more than any other game in my steam library, and I've been very excited for this new dlc AND the free patch, which I will both cover in this review - my first one and also pretty long, personal and detailed. First, let me explain why I was so eager to play Stellaris again with Overlord and the new patch.

I have never been fond of just conquering the whole galaxy while steamrolling every empire and just conquering all worlds for myself. I always felt that this lacked complexity and was a lot of struggling with revolting pops and warding off the penalties that you get for playing a really "wide" empire. So even before this dlc, I enjoyed playing the game more "tall" than wide, as a species that is powerful and excels at research and culture while having few very advanced systems and planets. One of the best playthroughs I ever had also involved me vassalizing half of the galaxy, leading a coalition of the (un)willing against my last enemy - that was before Overlord of course. So I thought: Overlord really improves my favourite style of play!

Well, about that - its a bit complicated. So, what do I think about the new expansion?

[b]First, the really cool stuff.[/b] In my view, playing "tall" received a buff. So far I have been able to use orbital rings to crank up my few specialized planets while adding even more useful stuff like spaceports and system defences. And the new Hyper Relays add a new dimension of strategic planning as it is extremely useful for rapid deployment along the major lines of operation - think of it as the intergalactic railway. Other megastructures I have yet to discover, but of course I'm excited for the catapult...

[b]Now, the mixed bag of mercenaries.[/b] In my experience, they can really be a pain. Got one of the biggest fleets in the galaxy? Fine, your neighbour with "pathetic" military force can still attack you because he saved all his cash for a huge-ass merc fleet. Oh, and by the way: AI loves mercenary fleets and WILL push hard for resolutions that curb your own nav cap while making the use of mercs necessary for wars unless you don't care being in breach of galactic law. I'd like to see more diversification here: not all AI empires should enjoy PMCs and mercs like that, it should be contested a bit more. Pacifist empires enjoying merc fleets that are presented as "peace-keeping professionals" is a bit absurd. In my case, I was attacked by a weaker neighbour that actually was able to send superior fleets my way, so I was forced to hire mercs too to repel the attack and remind him of his place in the galaxy. All in all it was fun though as it makes playing against weaker empires more challenging.

[b]My major complaint really is the new system of vassal management and contracts.[/b] To be fair, this has been introduced in the free patch, but the Overlord dlc really builds on this, so it has to be noted here. It has been criticized by other players, some of them really angry - and I think they have a point. In my case, one of the first wars I waged was against a direct neighbour and rival empire that could have become a problem in the long run. I destroyed his fleets and occupied all his planets, making him my subject. So one could expect that I will be able to force terms on him that he might not enjoy. But the mechanic really works a bit like federations worked before: The AI can simply refuse terms that are not benefical, even though the player just destroyed them in a war of subjugation, basically severely limitng YOU - the new all-powerful overlord. I was not able to assign the new vassal roles precisely because of this problem. This is really, really irritating as it can make vassals pretty useless. There is however a tendency I noticed: If you have a vassal for a longer period of time, you can gradually tighten their contracts. But this really takes far too long to be viable againt all those giant "I will steamroll everything in my path"-empires.

[b]My call for the devs would be to fix this mechanic to account for the balance of power:[/b] Once someone is your vassal, your own military capabilities - that you could use to enforce your will by violent means - should be far more important for changing contracts. This way, the absurd imbalance between large interstellar overlords and small, broken and beaten empires could be taken into account. Or you could force your vassal to accept terms they don't like, damaging the relationship between overlord and vassal in a way that will make the vassal disloyal, plotting against you to overthrow your oppressive rule.

TL;DR: So - the main selling point of this dlc seems a bit broken because the mechanic introduced in the free patch is broken. Why do I still recommend this game? Because I believe in Paradox' devs to fix this stuff and make the game better. I sincerely hope they will fix this soon because this would unlock the true potential of the expansion while balancing "wide" vs. "tall" play, making it a much-needed rework. In the meantime I will treat my vassals all nice and respectful of course [strike]because I don't have a choice[/strike] because I'm a nice guy.

Hope you enjoyed this personal account and review, have fun!
